reviewText: The 39 Steps, 2010 filmRichard Hannay returned from South Africa a rich man. He is bored and walks the streets. [Without a hat!] Another man runs in fear for his life. Mr. Scudder rushes into Hannay’s flat for safety. [The carrying of pistols dates this story as before 1922.] Scudder explains himself; he is an independent agent who learned of an assassination plot and wants to warn the British Secret Service. [Wouldn’t it be better to inform Vienna?] Foreign spies show up to stop a leak. Hannay rushes out, a Police Constable arrives but doesn’t believe Hannay’s story about the murder! Hannay wants to meet Captain Kell, but can’t. He will go to Scotland to investigate on his own. A newspaper reports the murder, the police are searching for Hannay. The police search the train but miss a disguised Hannay. [Believable?] On the road a biplane flies toward him and fires a machine gun at him. [Anachronism.] So do men in an automobile. Can he escape? He finds a car.Hannay is mistaken for a political candidate. Those spies locate him but he escapes again! Miss Sinclair, a Suffragette, helps him. There is a car chase (for action). But the pair are caught and taken to a mansion. Professor Fischer greets them. He will torture Victoria unless Hannay turns over that notebook with its coded message. Can they escape? Will they find explosives in that cellar? After the escape Miss Sinclair recovers that notebook! [She has talents.] They find food and shelter at a small inn. Can they decipher that coded message? Can they warn Captain Kell. In the morning when they see those foreign agents coming they bicycle away to safety. Will Sir George help them? Hannay says goodbye to Victoria. The next day Hannay goes to that castle and finds a surprise! The British Secret Service knows about Hannay. Hannay surmises the name of the traitor! There is a secret message (written in milk) on a blank page.Victoria and Hannay return to search that now empty mansion. They find a clue, and locate the spies’ meeting place. Shots are fired! A German U-boat surfaces, but it submerges before the spies can reach it and leave the country. British forces arrive to arrest the spies. Will there be a surprise for a tragic ending? Four months later there is war. Hannay is now in uniform. [Scottish troops wear khaki kilts, another anachronism.] There is a promise of a happy ending “after the war”.The older versions of this novel are better. The changes made it more interesting and exciting, so its worth watching. Do some parts of the plot seem implausible? The idea of an innocent man charged with murder provides a good basic plot for an adventure story. Can a modern day version be produced today? The movie “North by Northwest” was inspired by this story, and seems better. So too “Foul Play”. It is unbelievable that a young woman could work as an intelligence agent (unless she was an “actress” like Mata Hari). A man would be less noticeable than a young woman (all other things being equal). Victoria’s activity as a Suffragette could be useful for reporting on their activities. Weren’t there activists in those days?

reviewText: The actors are very likable and generally do their jobs well.  The color and setting made the film quite visually attractive.  But I am afraid that this upgrade in visual quality, only enhanced what can only be said to be an out-dated, coincidence heavy plot.  When Hitchcock presented this movie, pre-WWII audiences may have been able to appreciate the simplistic plot in a more sanguine way than modern audiences do.  The over-reliance upon coincidence is a measure of plot weakness.  Unfortunately, the 39 Steps does not stand the test of time despite a fine cast.
summary: New clothes for a dated plot

reviewText: I have never seen the original movie or knew anything about this when I saw it on Masterpiece. It is 1914 and Mr. Haney is bored until one day a man bursts into his apartment telling him he is a spy, giving him a notebook, and telling him the fate of England is at stake. Eventually that man is killed by German spys and Haney is framed for it. Haney escapes and aims to find the German spys to prove that he isn't a murderer.I admit, for the first 30 minutes I was bored and frustrated with the seeming plot holes. The police not only were easily able to find Mr. Haney (in a day before cell phones) but also chase him all over the Scottish Countryside. I mean does he have a GPS tracker on him? But once he meets Victoria... things are looking up. The two get caught by the German Spys and face death and possible torture. Haney is quickly drawn to the seemingly innocent Victoria and for me the highlight of the movie was the smoldering sparks between those two.In the end I was only modestly interested in the main spy plot but was very interested in the twist (which I kind of saw coming) and the relationship between the two leads.Something weird about the whole story, and I suppose history dictates the result, but unlike most stories of this type the plot may have be foiled but all was not wonderful again. So it was a bit on the bummer side.  Seemed like they should have fast forwarded somewhat more. But I was interested and recommend it.

reviewText: Although this version follows the John Buchan novel's story line, the result is claptrap and contrivance; unconvincing plot twists and a decidedly undramatic and clumsily filmed ending mar the production.  The countryside is lushly green -- Scotland looks as beautiful as I remember it, almost as much of a hunk as the leading man-- but the romance has few sparks.  Hitchcock's film had more humor, better drawn characters-- remember Peggy Ashcroft as the young wife in a loveless marriage [not in this version] -- and a believable, burgeoning romance between Robert Donat and Madeline Carroll.  Hitchcock's plot took liberties with the novel to create a great movie; this remake hews to the novel and results in mediocre television.

reviewText: Directed by: James HawesStars: Rupert Penry-Jones, Lydia LeonardRunning time: 85 min. NR - 2008In the recent years I have grown fond of anything made by BBC and this film is good example of why. This is the fourth major film version of the novel by John Buchan, with Hitchcock's original being the most well known. The story revolves around Richard Hannay who is given a notebook that contains Germany's secret plan to start World War I. After being framed for murder, Hannay must get the notebook to the Secret Service all while being chased by the cops and the Germans. The movie is a perfect blend of action, suspense and humor with that classic British touch.Don't be a pillock and buy this movie.

reviewText: I have lived in hope for years that we might one-day get a version of “The 39 Steps” that was faithful to the John Buchan source novel. I remember, of course, the 1935 Hitchcock version and being surprised to find no Mr. Memory, and no escape from the police across the Forth Road bridge when I picked up a copy of the book from the school library while at University in England. As I read the book it became apparent that Hitchcock had decimated Buchan’s original plot to the point that his 1935 film is “The 39 Steps” in almost name-only. The Hitchcock movie was remade in an almost frame-by-frame version in 1959 starring Kenneth More, so Hitch’s plot has become entwined in people’s memory, erroneously, as the “39 Steps:. In 1978 Robert Powell starred in another version of the film, and went someway to redressing the balance. For although Powell’s version is closer to the book, and had the movie set in the right time period, there were still areas where it diverted from Buchan’s plot. I assumed that we might never get a faithful version, that is until I happened across this BBC TV movie. Here at last is a TV movie that can accurately claim to be based on the Buchan book. The action moves thick and fast and we have a series of exciting escapes as Hannay tries to clear his name. In this version Hannay is again framed for a murder he didn’t commit and again travels to Scotland to clear his name and unravel the clues. There are tips of the hat to the Hitchcock version, with a hint of romance that was completely absent from the novel, and even a scene that harkens back to Hitchcock’s other spy movie “North By Northwest” as Hannay is buzzed by a biplane, but the pre-WWI era plot of Buchan’s book is largely intact. Bravo BBC for finally having the strength of character and courage to bring Buchan’s novel to the screen.
summary: Bravo BBC for finally having the courage to bring Buchan’s novel to the screen.

reviewText: Diplomat, intelligence officer, and adventure writer John Buchan's superb 1915 thriller "The 39 Steps" has been recreated several times on the big and small screens, most famously in Alfred Hitchcock's 1935 movie.  The 2008 BBC production is now available on DVD.  It stars Rupert Penry-Jones, familiar to PBS fans as Captain Wentworth in 2007's "Persuasion", as Richard Hannay, a resourceful Scottish mining engineer just returned from South Africa to the United Kingdom in 1914, as tensions rise with an aggressive Imperial Germany.At loose ends, Hannay encounters a British Secret Service agent on the run, who imparts a notebook full of coded messages before being murdered in Hannay's London apartment.  Sought by the police and the mysterious men who framed him, Hannay flees to Scotland.  There, he manages to decode enough of the notebook to realize a deadly foreign conspiracy is afoot against Britain, and sets out to expose the conspirators and clear himself.The story features a complicated espionage plot, some terrific location shooting in Scotland, an exciting action sequence involving a biplane (reminiscent of "North By Northwest"), and an unlikely but charming romance with a fiesty suffragette named Victoria Sinclair (Lydia Leonard).This version of "The 39 Steps" is loosely based on the John Buchan original, as re-imagined by screenwriter Lizzie Mickery.  It includes some new story elements, such as a two-part ending and Hannay's relationship with Victoria Sinclair.  Viewer opinions may well depend on their attachment to earlier versions.  This reviewer suggests enjoying "The 39 Steps" on its own terms for best results.

reviewText: Didn't know much about John Buchan, except that he died in office while serving as the king's representative in Canada (i.e. he was the Governor General) and that he wrote several romance adventures featuring the character of Richard Hannay (superbly brought to life here by Rupert Penry-Jones).  And, THE 39 STEPS was the first of them. Read it YEARS ago and the (exact) storyline and plot twists have pretty much been lost to the sands of time, but I believe that this adaptation is more or less like the novel in spirit and close enuf in plot CONSIDERING that it's only about 90 minutes long (and that some of the less politically correct material had to be excised for a 21st century audience).*SPOILER ALERT*The only substantive alteration to the original story, if I recall correctly, is the inclusion of a female companion who turns out to be a government agent (wonderfully played by Lydia Leonard), which, in my opinion, was a nice touch that added (more) romance and some funny comedic scenes to the story.  I also loved the cinematography -  in particular, the choice of "film stock" and the way the costumes and environment/setting/physical backgound (I'm having writer's block here) were beautifully similar or nicely contrasted, depending on the scene.  For example, in the second scene, where the agent Scudder isrunning for his life through several streets while the Hannay is languidly walking back to his apartment, Scudder's grey attire almost blends into the similarly coloured building and street stones (and would have if not for the wonderful sense of movement that the director created) whereas Hanney's black tux pleasantly contrasts with the same background.  The film aslo has a few nice homages to other films in it, which is another nice touch.*FINIS*About the only aspect of the film that I wasn't crazy about was the ending, 'tho it would be okay in retrospect if the producers made a sequel to this fine film - set in 1914 - with the male and female leads meeting up again.As for the criticism that this film doesn't hold up well to the Hitchcock version, I disagree.  Yes, that 1935 version was very good, but it, too, veered from the original Buchan story in several respects and its ending wasn't all that great either in that, after having Hannay running around for so long without a clue as to what to do, he is fortuitously informed as to where to go to get to the heart of the "39 Steps" mystery and, after he returns to England, the story wraps up  quickly - TOO quickly, in my opinion, anyway.By comparison, this 2008 version's plot unfolds at a nice pace and we get a better idea about the 39 Steps, which, in Hitchcock's version, was not a physical thing/place (as it was in the novel and is in this adaptation), but the name of the foreign spy ring.  Furthermore, unlike the 1935 film, this PBS Masterpiece Classic movie features voice-over narration by the protagonist, which is fitting becuz the Hannay stories were told in the first person.Although the two films are quite different, both are entertaining and interesting in their own ways.  However, if I HAD to choose (& taking their different production eras into consideration), I'd go with this version because of its better storyline and pacing and its sexy female agent (and I would think that most female viewers would prefer Penry-Jones' dashing, quick-thinking Hannay to Robert Donat's less resourceful one).Definitely worth your money and your time.Adapted by Lizzie Mickery and directed by James Hawes.

reviewText: THE 39 STEPS is one classy movie!  There are few who can pull off this mixture of humor, suspense, intrigue, and subterfuge the way the best of the British films can.  Lizzie Mickery's screenplay adaptation of John Buchan's novel tosses in a few unexpected ingredients and makes this early 1900s story blossom with suspense, hilarity, derring-do, and wonderful one-liners.  Director James Hawes paces the film so that there is never a dull moment in this chase toward staving off Germany's entry  into England in 1914. The acting is first rate and the cinematography (abetted by the beauty of Scotland) is sumptuous.The story is both simple and complex - simple in that it is a case of  British gentleman Richard Hannay (Rupert Penry-Jones)  falling upon an intruder (a spy who is murdered after passing a secret booklet containing codes regarding German information about meetings and proposed invasions in Richard's hands) who begins his moments of chase and intrigue as he attempts to save Britain from war.  Complex as along the way he encounters a suffragette Victoria Sinclair (Lydia Leonard) and her brother Hellory (Patrick Kennedy) and uncle Sir George (David Haig) all of whom play an integral part in the caper of the story. The entire cast of German spies and British counterparts is excellent and the story moves along with sufficient twists and turns (and a touch of romance) until a rather surprise ending.Part of the joy of these British whodunnits is the elegance of the language and the manner in which the story unfolds - with just enough escapes and frightful incidents balanced by smart dialogue.  Rupert Penry-Jones is a first class actor whose reputation should be assured with this film.  Highly Recommended for those rainy nights at home...Grady Harp, March 10
summary: Few outdo the British in mystery thrillers

Events taking place that make no sense e.g. Germans looking for self-taught spy go though whole apartment house and pick the one room he's hiding in. One German is suddenly dressed as milkman for no reason and other German suddenly and unnoticed comes through the back upper story fire escape door with no way of knowing what apartment to enter. Spy gets shot by, of course, apartment house owner's gun. Policeman arrives, asks dumb questions, allows apartment house owner to, of course, run out the back door.  The whole movie is like that and you're incredulously going "Sure!, Un-huh!"(4.) Airplane shooting looked very staged from the reason of it's existence to targeting and missing a single person in grassy fields to the brief car marginal chase scene in museum, can't get them dirty, cars to the submarine that appears for no reason and disappears just as quickly.Conclusion:Simply lacked drama because of it's predictability, staged acting, formula script, dumbness to the extreme storyline.

reviewText: It's hard not to bring up Hitchcock's adaptation, and I think any comparison to that 1935 classic simply sinks this 2008 BBC-produced rendition. But this new one still makes use of John Buchan's 1915 spy thriller as its backbone, although, again, certain liberties are taken. Rupert Penry-Jones is quite good as the lead character. He does that dashing, charming thing really well and he even almost makes that stereotypical British restraint seem like fun. There are chases and narrow escapes and espionage intrigue. There's a dose of stiff upper lip derring-do and a spirited romance. And I'm still not trying to bring up Hitchcock's adaptation.1914 finds British newspapers ominously hinting of a looming global war. It also finds Richard Hannay back home but quite fed up with England, or at least its dull, stuffy London men's club. But then intrigue surfaces in the shape of a fearful "freelance agent" (read: spy) who bursts into Hannay's room claiming that two German operatives are closing in from the outside. Hannay is incredulous, that is until the spy is fatally shot, prompting Hannay to go on the run, framed for the muder. But Hannay gets ahold of the flick's McGuffin, an enigmatic code book desperately sought by the villains. Top secret British military plans are compromised. The fate of England is at stake. A network of sinister enemy spies is operating on English soil. And Richard Hannay isn't bored anymore. Especially when the sexy, outspoken suffragette enters the picture.As mentioned, Rupert Penry-Jones is very serviceable as the resourceful hero, and there's a spark between him and the fiery Lydia Leonard, with whom he shares caustic banter that sometimes feels very screwball. This Hannay manages to also come up with quick-thinking ploys to get out of several sticky situations, including one which involves the pulling of a little girl's hair. Still, Hannay does get thrown for a loop late in the game. We're fairly certain he'll adapt.Danger lurking in the bucolic Scottish countryside. Hannay's ad-libbed speech at the meeting hall. A cozy evening spent at the inn, sans handcuffs. These are all familiar (and even welcome) elements. Okay, I didn't think much of the film's muddled climax and that very final scene or the unoriginal bi-plane attack. And, dammit, for some reason I do miss Mr. Memory ("Am I right, sir?"). But, in spite of all that, and because the wildly captivating "innocent man on the run" premise comes thru intact, this iteration of THE 39 STEPS is quite watchable. I tuned in initially because I really liked all five of John Buchan's Richard Hannay thrillers (six, if you count THE COURTS OF THE MORNING), and I guess I'll always tune in for whichever cinematic adaptation graces the screen. There's nothing quite like polite, well-behaved Englishmen being ripped out of their staid environs and put thru the wringer. Richard Hannay isn't quite James Bond. Hannay is more relatable, more human, and more my kind of hero.As a bonus, the DVD also features an amusing and witty advertisement for BBC America ("Hello there, and welcome to this DVD from BBC Video which you have either bought, borrowed, or stolen."). Other networks raring to hook in future viewers should take a peek at this ad, because that's how it's done.
summary: "I owe you an apology. It's very possible you're not the delusional maniac I first thought you were."

reviewText: I mostly enjoyed this remake of The 39 Steps: the pacing was good, the actors well cast, the scenery beautiful.  But why, oh why do screenwriters still imagine--in the 21st century--that they are writing a "strong" woman character by making her mindlessly opinionated, stubborn, arrogant and aggressively shrill?!!  Is it so inconceivable that a strong woman could be quietly, intelligently self-confident?  It's always disappointing to see a well-done film flawed by this kind of stereotyping.  My other complaint is that once the two main characters do come to understand one another and develop mutual trust, respect, and love, the screenwriters change the film's ending and sabotage the couple's possible future relationship, which was very sad.  Very unnecessary and very much a let-down.  I much prefer the quiet conclusion at the end of the original film, which leaves the viewer with a sense of a hopeful future, both for the couple and their country.

reviewText: It's the eve of World War I and the world will never be the same. The British public is going about its daily routine unaware of what the years ahead will bring. Enter mining engineer Richard Hannay who unwittingly becomes involved in a life and death struggle espionage thriller.The action begins immediately as a spy with vital information is murdered in Hannay's apartment. Hannay is the obvious suspect and he is soon on the run with a mysterious notebook handed to him by the spy. German agents are planning a surprise attack somewhere in the UK. Only Hannay can prevent it.Hannay ends up in Scotland where he meets a feisty suffragette named Victoria who is soon involved in his escapades.This BBC production is pure fun and entertainment. Action, romance and suspense fill the story. Hannay and Victoria are constantly trying to outrun the police and the German spies. The setting is lush and beautiful. The gorgeous Scottish countryside is a gem. The 1914 cars, clothes and setting are a delightful step back in time.There is a quick reference to "39 Steps" that gave the original book and movies their name. I thought those steps would be more important in the story but it really is a trivial, barely mentioned part of the story.I haven't seen the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock version of THE 39 STEPS. It is one of his classics and I plan to see it. I am sure this modern version can't compare but can stand on its own merits. I'm a fan of Rupert Penry-Jones from MI:5 so I wanted to see him in a different role and I was not disappointed.This BBC production of THE 39 STEPS.
summary: TOP QUALITY PRODUCTION AS ONLY THE BBC CAN DO IT

reviewText: THE 39 STEPS is the quintessential spy novella by John Buchan and was written in 1915. It is set in pre-WWI England and is the first Buchan novel featuring Richard Hannay, a British Everyman, a mining engineer by trade. Bored by England and ready to return to South Africa, Hannay discovers a corpse and a crytic notebook in his sitting room and sets out on an intriguing adventure.In anticipation of viewing the Masterpiece Classic Theatre presentation of this BBC production of THE 39 STEPS, I decided to re-read the original novella and do further research on the other films. The definitive Oxford World's Classics edition of the tale was a good choice for the re-read.  It contains the short novel along with a fascinating introduction by Christopher Harvie with bottom-of-the-page notes, three pages of Selected Bibliography, A Chronology of John Buchan's major writings, and 111 explanatory notes at the back of the paperback.And in the Harvie introduction, Buchan's biographer Janet Adam Smith discusses the films: "The first film adaptation was by Alfred Hitchcock in 1935, with Robert Donat as Hannay and dialogue by Ian Hay... It is still very watchable; more than can be said of its successors. Ralph Thomas made a version with Kenneth More in 1960, of which Halliwell's Film Guide comments that it was "practically a manual on how not to make a thriller"; the 1978 version, directed by Don Sharp and starring Robert Powell, was set in 1914, the only point at which its plot coincided with Buchan's book."Harvie also relates a bit of literary trivia: a comment by the British Weekly, the maker-and-breaker of literary reputations, in its July 1, 1915 review:We have everything here that can be wished---an excellent cipher story, with one or two points of novelty, a murder, a big subterranean business, a flight in a stolen motor-car, a monoplane floating with deadly intent, a Radical candidate, and all the rest. Not all the rest, for the woman has not yet appeared on the scene. But nobody must miss the tale.The British Weekly had a while to wait for the woman to appear. No prominent woman appears in the book and Hitchcock had only two minor female characters in his film.(The re-read and research paid off handsomely. This production is excellent, well-acted, beautifully filmed.  Rupert Penry-Jones plays Hannay...and the addition of Lydia Leonard as a beautiful suffragette is appropriate and exciting.)

reviewText: As a fan of the original Hitchcock version of this film, I went into the update with the old one in my head but it held up very well. The hero is ably played by Rupert Penry Jones (of MI5 fame, among other things) and the heroine, though a suffragette in this version, is also deftly handled and only just a tiny bit too modern for the period. It moves along quickly and adheres rather more accurately to the book The 39 Steps than the Hitchcock version does and all of the acting from the whole cast is well done. The plot is intricate enough to be interesting without being too confusing to follow and though I thought a small coda at the end felt a little awkward, it closed the film well so all in all I call this a  good romantic spy thriller in the period vein.
summary: Great updating of the old film

reviewText: Comparisons are to be expected, both with Alfred Hitchcock's 1935 great film (the only other version I've seen) and with the ones from 1959 or 1978.  Produced for television by the BBC, this version isn't too bad.  There are differences of course.  Set in 1914, Richard Hannay (Rupert Penry-Jones) is a Brit who has been working as an engineer in South Africa.  On holiday in London and bored with upper class nightlife, he gets all he bargained for when a man (not a woman as in Hitchcock's version) barges in on him as he enters his apartment.Scudder (Eddie Marsan) had been running from someone as the film opens.  It turns out Scudder is a double agent and has secured a German code book.  When he is killed by German agents in Hannay's apartment, Hannay is on the run given the book by Scudder before his demise.  One big difference in this film from the 1935 includes a middle section where Hannay comes upon a man and his wife who provide refuge for the night.  That plot point is excised from this version.Hannay does come across a woman (Lydia Leonard) and her brother (Patrick Kennedy) who provide temporary cover for Hannay as he escapes across the Scottish countryside, running from the German thugs and the police who suspect him of killing Scudder.  Penry-Jones is good as Hannay but Ms. Leonard seemed a little stiff.  They never had the give-and-take comedic chemistry between Robert Donat and Madeleine Carroll in the original.  As the couple run down the 39 steps leading from the stone house to the boat dock, the film has a surprising twist to end the story.  It is certainly worth a look.
summary: 3 1/2 stars for a satisfactory adaptation of John Buchan's novel

reviewText: I expected a remake of the famous Hitchcock film, but although this one does followthe original John Buchan premise in the novel that started it all off,it lacks the details that make Hitchcock's version so crazy andfascinating, such as Mr. Memory. There is a Hitchcockian touch--no spoiler here--onthe protagonist's train ride. I won't say what it is, but it really brings back theunnerving fantasy-realism you get in Hitchock's thrillers. There is also the problemthat the two leads often put themselves into ridiculously dangerous situations in a waythat nobody would in real life. Still, the thing moves along at a good clip, the playersare fine (especially the two leads), and the DVD, though made for television, hasthe roomy presence of a film.

reviewText: John Buchan introduced us to the unintentional spy Richard Hannay in the book the 39 Steps. The success of the book was such that there would be several more Hannay, the British spy thrillers and a fairly significant filmography growing from the text itself and the basic plot line. Hitchcock would do perhaps the most famous of the 39 Steps movies but also at least two other movies based on the same idea.This BBC 2010 release is not the best version from the existing broad selection. In this I must go against the bulk of the reviewers here at Amazon. Ultimately this version felt a little bit too deliberately modernized in how it handles the Buchan women and a general feel of everybody going through the motions.The principal action sequences are briskly paced but one can about hear the director calling out in that classic London Bobby tone of voice "to move along" for the next shot for the next chase the next something or another as the movie moves along in an orderly fashion to its fairly inevitable climactic awkwardly shot shootout.Not content to give us the feisty independent thinking suffragette, Victoria Sinclair (Lydia Leonard) this production has to screen out any female characters who might have been seen as weak or victims while elevating Victoria into something more than the strong character Buchan had originally presented. Had this nod to the sensitivities of the modern audience been a little less obvious and a little less at the expense of at least one noteworthy female character I think I would not have cared.This version of the 39 Steps is not bad it just isn't that good. There better versions available. I can't see any real reason for getting this one unless like me you are looking to collect several of the variations. As a rental or some other one time viewing this 29 Steps is an acceptable reason to heat up the popcorn and bring the family, youngsters included to the big screen TV.

reviewText: This story takes place in a favorite era of mine for the cars driven and the clothing worn by the upper classes in England at that time were such a joy to behold. Perhaps it was also that they had manners back then and a lot of us need a refresher course there. The principal leads are so attractive and their acting is believable, it's just the dialogue in one or two tiny places that seems a bit stilted.  The action moves right along and our hero leaves a few femmes suffering from shortness of breath and also momentary outrage; but love conquers all.  Plus the Germans depicted here were so bad they deserved to come to a bad end. I saw this on Masterpiece Theater, recorded it, and watched it so often that I tracked it on Amazon and when the price came down a bit, snagged the DVD.  Now I sleep better at night, knowing I can watch it whenever I please. An added plus was their use of the "broom handle" Mauser; my favorite handgun, perhaps someone will give me one for writing this review.

reviewText: Rupert P.-J. is in virtually every set-up of this nicely freshened-up and well-written 39 Steps, and that's a good thing.  Ironically enough, Mr. P.-J. is the first actor in memory since Cary Grant to make pajamas look sexy--but that's only one scene.  Most of the time he is avoiding an unfair murder rap bashing around London in blood-splattered white tie or Scotland in dynamite-scorched Saville Row tailoring, both of which he wears rather well, given how inappropriate the wardrobe for either locale.Lydia Leonard makes a dandy sidekick/love interest as the suffragette/undercover agent of the British Secret Service.This Amazon/Masterpiece presentation is more than a bit of a tease when they call this "Episode 1" because regrettably, it's all too obvious one show is all we are going to get.  Too bad.  Rupert P.-J. creates a compelling character whom it would be entertaining to follow and watch develop a la Inspectors Linley or Morse, et. al. He has all the makings of the classic BBC cloak-and-dagger hero. It should have been easy enough to come-up with more story lines to construct an entire series around defending the homeland from dirty German tricks during WW I and good for at least a half dozen seasons.Meanwhile, who knew Robert P.-J. was a Bond-class stud-puppy?  The Imdb.com chats favourably compare him to both Daniel Craig and James Purefoy, but clean-cut Penny-Jones is by far the classier act, not nearly so louche as Purefoy and infinitely more emotionally available--stiff upper lip and all--than Craig.It's time to both take a gander at Penny-Jones's work in Whitechapel and give a second glance toward MI-5, which fell somewhere short of enthralling when last we looked.  One suspects The 39 Steps will remain a challenging act to follow.
summary: Rupert Penny-Jones carries the show . . . quite handsomely, too

reviewText: Having seen and loved (and owning) Hitchcock's masterful 1935 version I wasn't sure that this was going to be all that.  Happily I can write that this is all that and more.  Covering the plight of one Richard Hannay, a Mining Engineer back in London from Africa on the eve of World War One and voice-overing that his life is just too dull.  In one of those "watch what you wish for" deals, he's within minutes on the run from both the police who think he murdered the freelance spy who invaded his apartment asking for help and the German spies determined to get the notebook said spy left on him.The film does have nods to Hitch's original: the milkman (in a delightful twist), the servant girl charmed by our man Hannay, new play on "Mr Memory" and a great nod to both "North by Northwest" and the helicopter scene in the original with an armed bi-plane.  If you want to be didactic then there are some inaccuracies: most of the cars used are later than the period.  But in this case I say get over it and enjoy the twists on both the book and the Hitchcock version.  Heck, get both and have a double feature!

reviewText: I'm a major Hitchcock fan so I don't use those words lightly. I think that when it comes right down to it, this movie works better than any of the other versions I've seen because it balanced the suspense and the light humor and romantic plot much better. The actors had a lovely natural chemistry, and they completely melted into their roles. Rupert Penry-Jones is one of those actors that has it all: looks, charisma, and a keen intelligence. He approaches every role I've seen him in with meticulous care, you can see that he really views his art as a craft and you never get a false or self-important note.Lydia Lenard is delightful as Victoria Sinclair: aristocrat, spy, suffragette, sometimes embroiderer. This is a very hard role to pull off because if you go too heavy-handed with either of these facets you risk moving into a cartoon instead of a character. Well... I suppose you can't say that about her penchant for embroidery, but I'm an avid embroiderer myself so... What I like about Victoria is that while she's perfectly willing to verbally cut an opponent to pieces to defend her feminism, she's also genuinely funny, compassionate, and can admit when her opponent makes a valid point. She makes an incredibly believable Edwardian spy, and while she's not a ravishing beauty, she is luminous with sparkling eyes, a charming grin, and a refined sensuality that compliments her leading man.The script and the direction is top-notch, so kudos to James Hawes and Lizzie Mickery. The homage to North by Northwest, was brilliantly woven in naturally, and a lovely touch to honor "The Master of Suspense." The locations in Scotland were exquisitely shot capturing their beauty and using the finicky weather to it's best advantage.Watch this with a hot cup of tea or coco and enjoy.

reviewText: It was a pretty good video, until the silly end.  Why have a decent plot and then throw it away in the last 20 seconds with a scene that is completely incongruous with the rest of the video?
